heroDescription: Detroit, known as the Motor City, is a hub of innovation and manufacturing.
landscapeDescription: Detroit's economy is diversifying beyond automotive, with growth in tech and healthcare. The city is revitalizing its urban core, attracting new businesses.
uniqueNeeds: Detroit requires strategic investment in tech and housing to ensure sustainable growth and mitigate risks.
citySpecificRiskAdvice: Detroit's heavy reliance on automotive poses risks; diversify into tech and healthcare. Real estate is volatile; watch for market bubbles. Flooding and winter storms are concerns.

sections.title: Economic Growth
sections.description: According to BEA (2023), Detroit's GDP growth is projected at 3.5%, driven by tech and healthcare sectors.

sections.title: Wealth Demographics
sections.description: According to Census (2023), the median income in Detroit is $52,000, reflecting economic recovery and growth.

sections.title: Advisor Specializations
sections.description: Based on BLS (2023), financial advisors in Detroit are increasingly specializing in real estate and tech investments.

sections.title: Cost of Living
sections.description: According to BLS (2024), Detroit's cost of living is lower than the national average, making it attractive for new residents.

sections.title: Real Estate Market
sections.description: According to Zillow (2024), Detroit's housing market is recovering, with prices rising but still affordable compared to national trends.

sections.title: Business Environment
sections.description: According to Fortune (2024), Detroit's business climate is improving, with incentives for startups and tech firms.
